item.title: Part 1: Foundations & ‚ÄúEight Great Ideas‚Äù
item.description: Preface # The preface starts with a motivation to read this book - professionals of every computing specialty should understand both hardware and software. This point was emphasized when the authors mentioned the switch from uniprocessor to multicore microprocessors (which will be emphasized many more times throughout Chapter 1).

item.title: Part 2: Inside the Machine ‚Äì Abstraction Layers & Technologies
item.description: Below Your Program # For computers to run complex applications, there needs to be some sort of translation. Computers can only run simple operations; if we were to write the program for example for this website (although a simple application) - we need so much effort and time.

item.title: Part 3: Performance, Power & the ‚ÄúSea Change‚Äù
item.description: Performance # When you are choosing a computer, how should you choose? Is it the computer that performs operations the fastest, one that does the most work, or the one that consumes least power?

item.title: Part 4: Real-World Examples & Wrap-Up
item.description: Benchmarking the Intel Core i7 # SPEC CPU Benchmark # If you had 2 computers, how would you know one of them performed better than the other? Whichever computer that completes the task faster is the better computer.

item.title: Internship Timeline
item.description:
Motivation for the internship:
#

I am passionate about forging a career in research and innovation within computer engineering. This internship offers a unique opportunity to translate my theoretical knowledge into hands-on expertise by designing and building a processor from the ground up.

item.title: Week 1
item.description: Week 1 Learning Log (May 19‚Äì23, 2025) # 1. Objectives # FPGA Architecture & Tools Understand FPGA internal architecture: CLBs (LUTs, muxes, flip-flops), on-chip SRAM/Block RAM Install and configure Vivado/Vitis 2022.

MIPS (Microprocessor without Interlocked Pipeline Stages) a classic RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) architecture simplicity, efficiency, and ease of pipelining. clean, regular instruction formats five-stage pipeline found in embedded devices where intruction set is nearly invisible, so it is hard to find a computer to download and run mips programs

item.title: Bi-stable Flip Flop
item.description: At the heart of an SRAM cell lies a bistable flip-flop, which is a circuit capable of holding one of two stable states: logic ‘0’ or logic ‘1’. This flip-flop is typically constructed using two cross-coupled inverters

item.title: Configuration Logic Block
item.description: The architecture of FPGAs rely heavily on Configuration Logic Blocks (CLBs). When you look at it, it is essentially a matrix of these CLBs, wired together by the device’s programmable interconnects.

item.title: LUT
item.description: Definition # Look up table is a memory. Instead of recomputing a circuit or a logic function every time, we compute and store in LUTs. Then depending on the input, FPGA looks up from the table and output that result.

item.title: SRAM
item.description: SRAMs are static memory. They are implemented using 6 transistors usually and because of that more expensive. Fills 2 needs: direct interface with CPU at speeds not attainable by DRAMs replace DRAMs in systems with very low power consumption In 1st use, SRAM serves as cache memory, interfacing between DRAMs and the CPU For 2nd use, SRAM is used instead of DRAM.

item.title: Week 2
item.description: Week 2 Learning Log (May 26‚Äì30, 2025) # 1. Objectives # HDL Implementation & Simulation Implement and simulate the following combinational primitives: 4-bit Subtractor (subtractor4.v) 2-to-1 Multiplexer (mux2to1.v) 4-to-1 Multiplexer (mux4to1.

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
Week 3 Learning Log (June 2‚Äì6, 2025)
#

1. Objectives
#

  • ALU Implementation & Testing
    • Design a simple 4-bit ALU using Vivado IP Integrator arithmetic blocks (alu_bd.v)
    • Verify functionality via testbench and hardware simulation
  • FPGA Design Flow
    • Meet with Sanka to review end-to-end FPGA design flow (synthesis, implementation, place-and-route)

item.title: Week 4
item.description: üìÖ Monday, June 9 # Moving from Hall 2 to Hall 4 üìÖ Monday, June 2 # Finish writing the chapter 1 arcticles (Patterson and Hennessy) Read about Chapter 1, 2, and 4 from Sarah L.
